line_item.specifications: Basis of Design: Greenheck SP-A110, 500 CFM, 0.25" SP. See Fan Schedule on M0.1 for details.
line_item.notes: There is a conflict in the documents. The fan schedule on M0.1 lists EF-4 and EF-5 as 'EXISTING', but the remodel roof plan M2.3 and electrical power plan E3.0/schedule E5.0 clearly show them as new installations. The bid should be based on providing new fans.

line_item.specifications: Provide insulated condensate drain piping from each new RTU to the nearest roof drain or scupper. Route per manufacturer's instructions and best practices.
line_item.notes: This is a required component for all AC units but is not explicitly shown or detailed on the plans. Scope must be included.

line_item.specifications: Provide and install factory controls, wall-mounted timer switches, or a time clock for all new equipment. Disregard DDC system requirements.
line_item.notes: Scope clarified per Addendum No. 1. This simplifies the control requirements significantly.

line_item.specifications: Perform air balancing of the complete heating and HVAC systems per the SMACNA Balancing and Adjustment Manual. Adjust air quantities to within 5% of design values. Submit final report.
1.0-inch thick fiberglass pipe insulation with factory applied all-service jacket on all interior storm drainage piping.
line_item.notes: Required per mechanical specifications but not explicitly shown on plans.

line_item.specifications: Provide all necessary hangers and supports for new interior rain leader and overflow piping per UPC and manufacturer requirements.
line_item.notes: Standard means and methods, not detailed on plans.

line_item.specifications: Test the rainleader systems per the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC).
Provide and install a fused or non-fused disconnect switch within sight of each piece of mechanical equipment, as required by NEC.
line_item.notes: Quantity to match number of new RTUs and Fans.

updates.description: Exhaust Fan (EF-1, EF-2, EF-3) and associated appurtenances
updates.notes: Located in Weight Room, Racketball Courts. Demolish fan, wiring, controls and all associated appurtenances. Patch wall to match adjacent construction materials.
Typical of two locations. System includes power connection kit, end seal, thermostat, and HOA control panel in Janitor Closet per detail E4.0/2. Requires coordination with Plumbing and Civil.
This is part of Additive Alternate #1. All associated demolition, roofing, structural, mechanical, and electrical work must be included in this alternate price.
This is part of Additive Alternate #2. All associated demolition, roofing, structural, mechanical, and electrical work must be included in this alternate price.

gaps_identified.description: Conflict between Fan Schedule on M0.1 and Remodel/Electrical Plans. M0.1 lists EF-4 and EF-5 as 'EXISTING', while M2.3 (Remodel Roof Plan) and E5.0 (Electrical Schedule) show them as new equipment to be powered. The bid should be based on providing new fans as shown on the remodel and electrical plans.
gaps_identified.recommendation: Clarify with the architect, but assume new installation for bidding purposes as it represents the greater scope.

gaps_identified.description: Condensate drain routing and termination points for new RTUs are not shown on the plans.
gaps_identified.recommendation: Assume drains will be routed to the nearest existing roof drains. The Mechanical contractor will need to field-verify routes and include sufficient labor and materials for insulated piping.

gaps_identified.description: Existing conditions and available space in the main electrical room for the new 400A main breaker, new Panel 'MECH', and new feeder terminations are not detailed.
gaps_identified.recommendation: A mandatory site visit is required for the Electrical contractor to assess existing conditions, verify space, and identify any potential conflicts or challenges with the specified upgrades.

ai_observations.title: Coordination of Heat Trace Installation
ai_observations.insight: The heat trace system is an electrical scope item (E3.0, E4.0) that must be installed on plumbing (rain leaders, M2.2) and civil (underground leaders, C1.0) piping. The installation must be completed by the electrician before the plumber insulates the interior piping and before the civil contractor backfills the exterior trenches. Failure to coordinate this sequence will result in rework and delays.
suggested_actions: The GC must schedule a specific pre-installation meeting for the heat trace scope with the Electrical, Plumbing, and Civil subcontractors.
The electrician must be notified with sufficient lead time to install the heat trace cable on the exposed pipes.
The plumber and civil contractor must not proceed with insulation or backfill until the heat trace installation and any required inspections are complete.

ai_observations.title: Responsibility for Motor Starters
ai_observations.insight: The electrical schedule on sheet E5.0 indicates that motor starters for the new mechanical equipment are to be provided 'BY MECH'. This is a common point of confusion. It means the Mechanical contractor is responsible for purchasing and mounting the starters, while the Electrical contractor is responsible for providing the power wiring to and from the starter.
suggested_actions: Confirm the Mechanical subcontractor has included the cost of all required motor starters in their bid.
Confirm the Electrical subcontractor has included the labor to wire to and from the starters, but not the material cost of the starters themselves.
Coordinate the location of starter mounting between trades.

ai_observations.title: Equipment Substitutions and Coordination
ai_observations.insight: Addendum No. 1 and the Mechanical Submittal Review letter from Jernstrom Engineering (dated March 16, 2023) both address equipment substitutions. Substitutions are allowed, but the contractor is responsible for verifying duct connections, electrical parameters, and any additional costs. The review letter explicitly notes that the submitted (substituted) equipment loads for RTU-1 through RTU-6 *exceed* the basis of design loads, requiring coordination with the electrical trade.
suggested_actions: If bidding a substitute equipment package, the Mechanical contractor must provide the new electrical load data to the Electrical contractor immediately.
The Electrical contractor must review the new load data and adjust their bid for any required increases in wire size, conduit size, or breaker ratings.
The GC must ensure any cost impacts from substitutions are captured in the bid, as they will not be eligible for change orders.

overall_assessment.summary: The deep-dive into Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing trades confirms a well-defined but highly coordinated scope. Key additions include missing but required items like condensate drains, pipe insulation, and TAB services. The most significant risks stem from coordination failures, particularly regarding the sequence of heat trace installation and the electrical impact of mechanical equipment substitutions, which is explicitly called out in post-bid correspondence. A document conflict regarding new vs. existing exhaust fans needs to be bid conservatively (as new). The extensive electrical panel and feeder upgrades in an existing facility necessitate a pre-bid site visit to mitigate risk.
